VOL. XXXI, No. 31
JAY TRACK TEAM APPEARS
WEAKER THAN THAT
OF LAST YEAR
Loss of Hills, Gilpin, He3rn and Other
Stars Will Be Keenly Felt
Says Coach Edwards

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 15, 1927

SOPHOMORE CLASS
DUES NOW PAYABLE
Sophomore class dues of
five dollars are now payable
to the class treasurer or the
members of the finance committee. According to Samuel
M. Hecht, class treasurer, it
is advisable to pay the fees as
soon as possible, since after a
certain date, which will be determined later, a weekly fine
of ten cents will be imposed
delinquents.
on
Besides
Hecht, George Glazier, John
Turnbull, Bernard McCurley
and Irving Gordon are also
authorized to receive dues.

DR. SINGEWALD TELLS OF
RECENT EXPEDITION
TO SPAIN
Hopkins Geologist Illustrates Talk on
Fascinating Old Country With
Many Slides

SPEAR TO CAPTAIN
FRESHMAN DEBATERS
P. W. Spear was selected
chairman of the freshman debate team at the tryouts held
on Friday. Dr. French announced that Milton Blumenfeld and M. D. Ghent will be
the other members of the team
to debate on the subject of
freshman regulations; G. R.
Seidel will alternate.
The number and ability of
the candidates was very pleasing to Dr. French, who selected the team.

The necessity of earlier elections in all activities was. emphasized by President Farinholt at
a meeting of the Student Activities Council on Friday, February
11. The advancing of such elections will make appointments to
the Activities Council fall on earlier dates, Farinholt stated.

GOOD NEWS

rather than to be turned over to

Seniors who have been award-

Miss Davis, assistant to the registrar, announced that twenty-three
new students have entered the University for the second term. Sixteen are graduate students, five having registered in the College of
Arts and Sciences, and two in the
Engineering School. One foreign
student, a graduate in history from
Japan, was admitted.
The Committee on Academic
Rules and Regulations has sent out
letters, restating and explaining the
rule giving the number of courses
allowed for graduation in which the
student has a mark of below seven.
A student may get a mark of under
seven in courses amounting to
twelve points (if one is a laboratory course, sixteen are allowed).
If marks of under seven are secured in courses totaling over this
amount, the total number of units
of the courses below seven are added and twelve subtracted. The remainder is the number of units that
may not be counted for graduation.

ior year and have again earned

JAY TRACK TEAM WEAKER

In the carrying through of the plans, we wish the "Y" all
the success it deserves. A plan which includes the undergraduate
gives him that feeling of satisfaction which springs from the
knowledge that be has not yet passed entirely out of the picture.

A day or two more, and the Musical Club will set out for
Norfolk with every expectation of winning an equal amount of
fame and a larger share of fortune than attended them on their
memorable southern tour two years ago. There is no reason
to suppose that they will not be successful. No fault can be
found with Norfolk, as those who made the former trip will
testify, and the Club is unquestionably good.
Not only has the Club been good, but its schedule has been
excellent, an achievement which is worthy of the highest praise.
The joint concert at Wilmington, the Norfolk trip, and the Home
Concert on February twenty-fifth are a fitting conclusion to a
good season, one which would be a credit to any club which
comes under the "smaller college" classification.
The credit for this belongs to the officers of the Club, who
have succeeded in getting out of the rut into which the Club lapsed
last year, and in continuing the traditions begun two years, ago.
We wish them the best of luck at Norfolk.

Whatever malice may have been in the heart of the NEWSLETTER editor after his paper was so completely "scooped" by
the Y News of last Wednesday was completely mitigated by the
article in question. The news that a new Y. M. C. A. Building
is almost certain to be erected in the near future is welcome, the
most welcome, in fact, that has found its way into the columns of
The "Y", Mr. Schaal in particular, is to be congratulated
upon the way in which the project has been handled thus far.
Levering Hall, we are told, is to be planned almost entirely with
regard to student needs. The campus, in so far as we are its
interpreters, appreciates the stand taken by the "Y" both because
it will go a long way toward relieving conditions which have become almost intolerable, and because of the spirit which prompted

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY /5, 1927

mom'

•IONM.

7a

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
Asserting that fraternities, as
they now exist in American colleges,
are antiquated, non-fraternity students at Syracuse University have
organized a Student Union, which
is now composed of 'several thousand members. This movement,
which is backed by the administration, may bring about the extinction of fraternities at Syracuse, although the condition is not yet serious.
*

*

*

It has recently been computed
that students at the University of
Southern California have saved the
University $15,000 by spending
three hours each morning cleaning
the campus. We wonder how
much they would have saved if they
had spent that three hours each
night studying.
*

*

*

Dean McCutchan of De Pauw
University recently offered as an incentive to attend the Clavilux concert, the fact that couples may be
assured that the auditorium would
be perfectly dark during the whole
concert. All very well, but we wonder why they don't dispense with
the performance itself so as to provide against any interruptions.
*

*

*

At the new John Wesley College
in Columbia, Illinois, dances, athletics, and fraternities are barred and
the use of liquor or tobacco is
tabooed. Why not ban students
and make a good job of it?
*

*

*

JOHN VAN DRUTEN WRITING NEW PLAY
WHILE VISITOR AT J. H. U. DORMITORY
"I like Hopkins so much that I've
come back again," John Van Druten, noted English playwright, declared in an interview today. Mr.
Van Druten got his first glimpse of
Hopkins life last fall when he gave
a talk at the Homewood Playshop.

DR. SINGEWALD EXTOLS
BEAUTIES OF SPAIN

mentioned the crude, almost medieval customs which still prevail among much of the Spanish
peasantry. The northern farmers still wear wooden shoes and
in many villages the streets are
very narrow. In some places bull
fights are staged in the town
court or square. Some of the
roads are good but the methods of
upkeep are antiquated shovels
are practically unknown in Spain,
dirt being packed in baskets or
sacks and carried to desired
places. Outside of some of the
cities and in the far south, people
live in caves cut into the hills,
finding them cheaper than ordi-

The disastrous effect of mid-year
examinations upon the human mind
and body was recently evidenced at
an English examination at the University of Detroit. The questions
had been handed to the students
and all were industriously engaged
in bewailing their lamentable fate.
Suddenly there was the sound of
a fall and the class was startled
to see one of its freshman members
stretched on the floor unconscious—

and smokeless cities, and are taken from a
report of the Mellon Institute.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 15, 1927

A Few To Accompany
Musical Club South

MANY RESPOND TO JAY
TRAVEL QUESTIONS
Campus Humorists and Artists Hard
at Work on Blue Jay's Travel Issue

Edward M. Passano, president of
the Musical Club, stated that any
undergraduate students who so desire, would be able to make the trip
to Norfolk on Thursday, along with
the Club members.
It is absolutely necessary, however, that due notification be given
Passano before Wednesday afternoon. According to Passano, several non-members have already signified their intention of taking this
trip.
In order to make the trip a most
appealing one, Passano has succeeded in getting reduced rates for all
Hopkins students. The price of
$12.70 will include transportation,
hotel accommodations and admittance to the concert, in fact, everything from Thursday night until
Sunday morning, except meals.

Answers varying from the sublime to the ridiculous have resulted
from the questionnaire on travel
which the Black and Blue Jay recently sent out. Many thought the
whole thing a joke and returned
humorous answers, while others
considered the questionnaire as a
serious matter and treated it in such
a manner. The Jay sent one of
the questionnaires to the College
Advertising Agency and as luck
would have it, it happened to be one
with foolish answers. The result
was that Leonard Dalsemer, advertising manager of the Jay had to
make a trip to New York to
straighten out the mix-up.
Those who sent in serious answers to the questionnaire may receive valuable information from the
Black and Blue Jay Travel Bureau.
The Jay has received literature from
all the important railroad and steamship lines in America and even from
some concerns in Great Britain.
The cover of the next issue of
the Jay, the travel number, has been
drawn by J. L. Hurwitz and represents a Buddha in an unusual pose.
The whole issue, from cover to
cover, will be concerned with the
humorous side of traveling. It is
to be a regular size issue, as the
Jay has discontinued its policy of
changing the size of its issues from
time to time.
According to Maxwell Cone, Business Manager of the Black and
Blue Jay, a banquet will be given by
that organization on April 11. The
place of the banquet has not as yet
been decided upon. Leaders of the
various activities on the campus will
be invited with the purpose of
drawing them more closely together.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 15, 1927

SOPHOMORE CLASS
DUES NOW PAYABLE
Sophomore class dues of
five dollars are now payable
to the class treasurer or the
members of the finance committee. According to Samuel
M. Hecht, class treasurer, it
is advisable to pay the fees as
soon as possible, since after a
certain date, which will be determined later, a weekly fine
of ten cents will be imposed
delinquents.
on
Besides
Hecht, George Glazier, John
Turnbull, Bernard McCurley
and Irving Gordon are also
authorized to receive dues.

DR. SINGEWALD TELLS OF
RECENT EXPEDITION
TO SPAIN
Hopkins Geologist Illustrates Talk on
Fascinating Old Country With
Many Slides

SPEAR TO CAPTAIN
FRESHMAN DEBATERS
P. W. Spear was selected
chairman of the freshman debate team at the tryouts held
on Friday. Dr. French announced that Milton Blumenfeld and M. D. Ghent will be
the other members of the team
to debate on the subject of
freshman regulations; G. R.
Seidel will alternate.
The number and ability of
the candidates was very pleasing to Dr. French, who selected the team.

GOOD NEWS

rather than to be turned over to

Seniors who have been award-

Miss Davis, assistant to the registrar, announced that twenty-three
new students have entered the University for the second term. Sixteen are graduate students, five having registered in the College of
Arts and Sciences, and two in the
Engineering School. One foreign
student, a graduate in history from
Japan, was admitted.
The Committee on Academic
Rules and Regulations has sent out
letters, restating and explaining the
rule giving the number of courses
allowed for graduation in which the
student has a mark of below seven.
A student may get a mark of under
seven in courses amounting to
twelve points (if one is a laboratory course, sixteen are allowed).
If marks of under seven are secured in courses totaling over this
amount, the total number of units
of the courses below seven are added and twelve subtracted. The remainder is the number of units that
may not be counted for graduation.

JAY TRACK TEAM WEAKER

In the carrying through of the plans, we wish the "Y" all
the success it deserves. A plan which includes the undergraduate
gives him that feeling of satisfaction which springs from the
knowledge that be has not yet passed entirely out of the picture.

A day or two more, and the Musical Club will set out for
Norfolk with every expectation of winning an equal amount of
fame and a larger share of fortune than attended them on their
memorable southern tour two years ago. There is no reason
to suppose that they will not be successful. No fault can be
found with Norfolk, as those who made the former trip will
testify, and the Club is unquestionably good.
Not only has the Club been good, but its schedule has been
excellent, an achievement which is worthy of the highest praise.
The joint concert at Wilmington, the Norfolk trip, and the Home
Concert on February twenty-fifth are a fitting conclusion to a
good season, one which would be a credit to any club which
comes under the "smaller college" classification.
The credit for this belongs to the officers of the Club, who
have succeeded in getting out of the rut into which the Club lapsed
last year, and in continuing the traditions begun two years, ago.
We wish them the best of luck at Norfolk.

Whatever malice may have been in the heart of the NEWSLETTER editor after his paper was so completely "scooped" by
the Y News of last Wednesday was completely mitigated by the
article in question. The news that a new Y. M. C. A. Building
is almost certain to be erected in the near future is welcome, the
most welcome, in fact, that has found its way into the columns of
The "Y", Mr. Schaal in particular, is to be congratulated
upon the way in which the project has been handled thus far.
Levering Hall, we are told, is to be planned almost entirely with
regard to student needs. The campus, in so far as we are its
interpreters, appreciates the stand taken by the "Y" both because
it will go a long way toward relieving conditions which have become almost intolerable, and because of the spirit which prompted

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY /5, 1927

mom'

•IONM.

7a

INTERCOLLEGIATE

NEWS
Asserting that fraternities, as
they now exist in American colleges,
are antiquated, non-fraternity students at Syracuse University have
organized a Student Union, which
is now composed of 'several thousand members. This movement,
which is backed by the administration, may bring about the extinction of fraternities at Syracuse, although the condition is not yet serious.
*

*

*

It has recently been computed
that students at the University of
Southern California have saved the
University $15,000 by spending
three hours each morning cleaning
the campus. We wonder how
much they would have saved if they
had spent that three hours each
night studying.
*

*

*

Dean McCutchan of De Pauw
University recently offered as an incentive to attend the Clavilux concert, the fact that couples may be
assured that the auditorium would
be perfectly dark during the whole
concert. All very well, but we wonder why they don't dispense with
the performance itself so as to provide against any interruptions.
*

*

*

At the new John Wesley College
in Columbia, Illinois, dances, athletics, and fraternities are barred and
the use of liquor or tobacco is
tabooed. Why not ban students
and make a good job of it?
*

*

*

JOHN VAN DRUTEN WRITING NEW PLAY
WHILE VISITOR AT J. H. U. DORMITORY
"I like Hopkins so much that I've
come back again," John Van Druten, noted English playwright, declared in an interview today. Mr.
Van Druten got his first glimpse of
Hopkins life last fall when he gave
a talk at the Homewood Playshop.

University of Wales, where he
taught Law before he started his famous career as a playwright.

Where there is smoke,there is destruction—
destruction of building, machinery and finished product. And even worse is the impairment of employes' health and efficiency.
Not alone as a civic duty, but equally as a
matter of plain commercial profit,your plant
should be a leader in the "SmokelessTown"
movement. Send today for our interesting
book,"Gas—The Ideal Factory Fuel".

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, FEBRUARY 15, 1927

A Few To Accompany
Musical Club South

MANY RESPOND TO JAY
TRAVEL QUESTIONS
Campus Humorists and Artists Hard
at Work on Blue Jay's Travel Issue

Edward M. Passano, president of
the Musical Club, stated that any
undergraduate students who so desire, would be able to make the trip
to Norfolk on Thursday, along with
the Club members.
It is absolutely necessary, however, that due notification be given
Passano before Wednesday afternoon. According to Passano, several non-members have already signified their intention of taking this
trip.
In order to make the trip a most
appealing one, Passano has succeeded in getting reduced rates for all
Hopkins students. The price of
$12.70 will include transportation,
hotel accommodations and admittance to the concert, in fact, everything from Thursday night until
Sunday morning, except meals.

Answers varying from the sublime to the ridiculous have resulted
from the questionnaire on travel
which the Black and Blue Jay recently sent out. Many thought the
whole thing a joke and returned
humorous answers, while others
considered the questionnaire as a
serious matter and treated it in such
a manner. The Jay sent one of
the questionnaires to the College
Advertising Agency and as luck
would have it, it happened to be one
with foolish answers. The result
was that Leonard Dalsemer, advertising manager of the Jay had to
make a trip to New York to
straighten out the mix-up.
Those who sent in serious answers to the questionnaire may receive valuable information from the
Black and Blue Jay Travel Bureau.
The Jay has received literature from
all the important railroad and steamship lines in America and even from
some concerns in Great Britain.
The cover of the next issue of
the Jay, the travel number, has been
drawn by J. L. Hurwitz and represents a Buddha in an unusual pose.
The whole issue, from cover to
cover, will be concerned with the
humorous side of traveling. It is
to be a regular size issue, as the
Jay has discontinued its policy of
changing the size of its issues from
time to time.
According to Maxwell Cone, Business Manager of the Black and
Blue Jay, a banquet will be given by
that organization on April 11. The
place of the banquet has not as yet
been decided upon. Leaders of the
various activities on the campus will
be invited with the purpose of
drawing them more closely together.
